answers.answer: The hemorrhage will not affect cataract surgery risk.  There are many causes of retinal hemorrhage which need to be evaluated:  hypertension, diabetes, use of blood thinners, anemia, leukemia, among others.  If the hemorrhage is very close to the optic nerve, this can be a risk factor for glaucoma.  Again, the hemorrhage per se will not increase the risks of cataract surgery.  It is possible that the cataracts are at the point that they are affecting the retina specialist's view of the retina, and that is the reason for suggesting removal.

I am confused when people say it can be caused by anemia. I have a genetic blood disorder and at times I experience extreme bouts of anemia called hemolytic anemia. Also, I have been tested for diabetes which I do not have but I do experience regular periods of very low blood sugar. Should I bring up these issues to my Retina specialist?

I'm very sorry about the problems with your eye health and vision.  Yours sounds like a challenging case and I can understand your concern.Dr. Fazio's comment that the retina specialist may need the cataracts removed so the back of the eye can be viewed also makes sense to me.  Although there are now lots of great imaging techniques for viewing the retina with the advent of OCT, the retina doctor may still want to 'visualize' the retina directly to assess any treatment for your nerve fiber layer bleeding and other retina problems.You should ask the retina doctors why they now feel cataract removal might be worth the risk of cataract surgery in a high myope with existing retina problems.There are certain blood disorders which can definitely affect the retina and bleeding in that area of the eye, so you should DEFINITELY discuss your history with your retina specialist.  You might want to prepare a list ahead of your next appointment detailing the diagnoses and treatment related to your blood disorder, so the doctor can quickly review it and then discuss it with you.In terms of diabetes, it's good that you do not have it.  High blood sugar from diabetes, rather than low sugar levels, is more commonly associated with damage to the eyes.  But you should also mention the low blood sugar issues to your doctor, as well as any other major elements of your medical history.  There might be something else that seems unrelated but could be affecting your eye health.Lastly, be sure to tell your retina doctor and cataract surgeon both about any meds or supplements you take, as some can affect bleeding and there may be some the doctors will want you to stop taking before any procedure.  I with you all the best with your future treatment.
